text:
Free speech is an ill-posed idea because it can incite violence? Not sure if that's what you're saying there?

I think we've all always agreed on the obvious exceptions to free speech (saying anything with powerful emotion that causes harm to others is the most obvious)

elements.text:
Free speech is an ill-posed idea because it can incite violence? Not sure if that's what you're saying there?

I think we've all always agreed on the obvious exceptions to free speech (saying anything with powerful emotion that causes harm to others is the most obvious)

text: Self-censoring and fear of speaking out due to fear of the consequences (from social shaming all the way to being beaten) is currently an everyday reality. Not the world I grew up in, and miss so much.

elements.text: Self-censoring and fear of speaking out due to fear of the consequences (from social shaming all the way to being beaten) is currently an everyday reality. Not the world I grew up in, and miss so much.

text: I should obviously add Soviet Russia and Maoist China to my list alongside Nazi Germany, by the way, since I'm trading in obvious examples!

elements.text: I should obviously add Soviet Russia and Maoist China to my list alongside Nazi Germany, by the way, since I'm trading in obvious examples!

text:
> I think we've all always agreed on the obvious exceptions to free speech (saying anything with powerful emotion that causes harm to others is the most obvious)
Citation required. To my knowledge speech is free _precisely_ because it is held to not cause harm. Radio Rwanda's broadcasts would not have run afoul of _Brandenburg_ (<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freedom_of_speech#Limitations>)

Above all, it's not clear to me that people have ever _agreed_ on the lines circumscribing free speech.

> Self-censoring and fear of speaking out due to fear of the consequences (from social shaming all the way to being beaten) is currently an everyday reality. Not the world I grew up in, and miss so much.
Again, citation required. I think the reputational consequences of speech have always been around, and we have all always grown up watching what we say. The expectation to speak without consequence is usually comorbid with some level of privilege. What _has_ changed in recent times (and this is the "new capability" I alluded to above) is that it's become easy to cast your voice far and wide. That makes it easy to cast your words _farther than you want_. It's not a difference in kind, merely one of degree. Like needing to unlearn some skills when switching from tennis to racketball.

You are permitted to compare the US to Nazi Germany and Soviet Russia and Maoist China the day we start throwing people in prison for being racist :wink: Facebook groups aren't quite there. Yet.

text: I’d prefer if we keep regional political discussions out of our community. There’s already enough of a presumption in software development that the world stops at the US border... I’m unable to escape American politics no matter where I look :confused:.

elements.text: I’d prefer if we keep regional political discussions out of our community. There’s already enough of a presumption in software development that the world stops at the US border... I’m unable to escape American politics no matter where I look

text: I know what you mean. I figured this thread is already busted (and simultaneously blessed by Ivan) on that score..

elements.text: I know what you mean. I figured this thread is already busted (and simultaneously blessed by Ivan) on that score..

text: It is American politics at this moment. But the original issue that Mozilla stated and asked to sign up for does not stop at any country border. In India we face a similar problem now. Tons and tons of mis-information. You just need to look out of your window and you will be amazed to see that the world is spread beyond the US border.
